This report presents 3 key findings from an analysis of Nutrition_Physical_Activity_and_Obesity. The analysis addressed 12 questions focused on exploring patterns, relationships, and insights within the data.

![](plot_1768932237417_0_0.svg)

This choropleth map displays adult obesity rates across the contiguous United States in 2023, with states colored on a gradient from green (lower rates) through yellow to red (higher rates). A clear geographic pattern emerges, with Southern and Midwestern states showing the highest obesity prevalence (above 35%), while Western states like Colorado and coastal states tend to have lower rates, revealing significant regional health disparities.

![](plot_1768932237417_1_0.svg)

This radar chart compares five key health indicators between Colorado and West Virginia in 2023, with the polygon area representing overall health burden. West Virginia (red) shows substantially higher values across all metrics—obesity, overweight status, physical inactivity, and low fruit/vegetable consumption—compared to Colorado (green), visually demonstrating the comprehensive health gap between one of the nation's healthiest and least healthy states.

![](plot_1768932237417_2_0.svg)

This grouped bar chart provides a direct numerical comparison of health indicators between Colorado and West Virginia in 2023, with percentage point differences annotated above each pair. West Virginia exceeds Colorado by 8-13 percentage points across all five metrics, with the largest gaps appearing in obesity (+12.8 pp) and physical inactivity (+13.1 pp), quantifying the substantial public health challenges facing the state.
